sections: At the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, Refresco ‚Äî a transnational corporation that produces and bottles soft drinks for major brands such as Tropicana and Gatorade ‚Äî had a single response to its staff about the public health crisis unfolding at its Wharton, NJ plant an hour outside of New York City: show up to work.

According to the workers at the plant and their union, employees exposed to the virus were denied time off, the factory remained open despite a broader economic shutdown, on top of the 12-hour shifts the company required. (Workers say the company used the pandemic to justify longer shifts, while Refresco claims the new policy went into place prior to the emergence of COVID-19). Outraged, the predominantly immigrant workforce formed a union, winning their first election in June 2021 in what was one of the largest blue-collar union victories during the pandemic.

One year later, New York-based private equity megafirm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., also known as KKR & Co., became a majority owner of the company. Now, workers claim that under KKR‚Äôs control, Refresco has been dragging its feet on negotiating a first contract with the union and pushing for draconian provisions such as only allowing workers to take weekends off once every eight weeks. KKR‚Äôs business model, meanwhile, depends on the pension funds of unionized teachers, firefighters, social workers, and bus drivers.

The plight of Refresco‚Äôs nearly 250 workers exemplifies one of the biggest problems facing American labor today: Union workers are, often unknowingly, funding the war on themselves by financing union busting activities through their pension funds.

‚ÄúRespect, Dignity, And Equality In Working Conditions‚Äù

For years, the top-down culture of overwork at Refresco‚Äôs plant in Wharton, New Jersey, has led to injuries, said C√©sar Moreira, an Ecuadorian immigrant to the U.S. who has worked at Refresco for nine years. ‚ÄúThey have shown repeatedly that they don‚Äôt really care about the bodies and health of the workers,‚Äù said Moreira. ‚ÄúThe accidents continue ‚Äî we had a worker fall off a ladder just in the last few months.‚Äù
Such a culture was particularly evident in the early months of the pandemic in 2020, when workers became ill and found little respite from Refresco management.
‚ÄúThere were many of our fellow workers who were sick with COVID at the beginning of the pandemic,‚Äù said Moreira. ‚ÄúOne of us was in the hospital for two weeks.‚Äù
The connection between overwork and injury is strong. A 2018
of occupational health studies concluded, ‚ÄúWorkers working long hours had a higher chance of experiencing occupational health problems.‚Äù

At Refresco, the long hours can lead to swollen legs that have not been properly treated, according to union complaints filed with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Some Refresco workers frequently work as long as 16-hour shifts.

Refresco stated that it had ‚Äúexceeded government guidelines‚Äù for COVID-19 risk management ‚Äúby providing our manufacturing employees with face masks in addition to other personal protection equipment before it became a recommendation or requirement,‚Äù and that ‚ÄúRefresco complies with all applicable labor laws.‚Äù
The conditions inspired workers to form a union.

‚ÄúWe began to meet, and we realized that only with a union would we have more power against the bosses,‚Äù said Moreira. ‚ÄúWe are workers who want respect, dignity, and equality in working conditions.‚Äù

Refresco employees chose to unionize in their first National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) election in June 2021. The following May, they won a second union election ordered by the NLRB after Refresco complained that the previous vote had started five minutes behind schedule due to an NLRB official being late.

‚ÄúOne Consecutive Saturday And Sunday Off Every Eight (8) Weeks‚Äù
While bargaining continues between Refresco management and the small and militant United Electrical, Radio, and Machine Workers of America (UE) union, documents obtained by

reveal that KKR ‚Äî in addition to generally slow-walking workers‚Äô path to a union contract ‚Äî has refused to accede to any worker demands that would create greater consistency in employees‚Äô home life.

KKR‚Äôs current contract proposal guarantees workers just one day off every 12 days, even if they are working 12-hour shifts. Moreover, KKR promises in the proposal to the union that ‚Äúall regular full-time employees shall have at least one consecutive Saturday and Sunday off every eight (8) weeks.‚Äù
In other words, these workers ‚Äî nearly all of whom make less than $20 an hour, with health insurance coverage that can cost more than $450 monthly ‚Äî would have just six weekends per year.
